homePanel.title: Californians are connected by their water.
homePanel.pg1: Water sustains our communities. The COEQWAL project helps Californians navigate the stateâ€™s complex water system by illustrating how it works and exploring data-driven ways water can be distributed.

introInterstitial.pg1: Over the past 150 years, we have built a highly-managed system to distribute water to cities, farms, ecosystems, and communities. We find ourselves in a moment where ecosystems are challenged, human right to water is not always being met, and we are facing the impacts of climate change.

paragraphs.pg1: Because of the geography of California, water rarely falls where it is most used. Most of California's water comes from Winter rains in the north.
paragraphs.pg2: Snowpack in the Sierra Nevada mountains creates natural reservoirs that release water throughout the Spring.
paragraphs.pg3: Surface water flows into tributaries to the Sacramento and San Joaquin Rivers,
paragraphs.pg5: and then out to the Pacific through the Golden Gate.
paragraphs.pg6: Groundwater is stored underground in aquifers and springs throughout the Central Valley and the mountains.
paragraphs.pg7: Ancient groundwater is interconnected and replenished by seasonal rains.

drawerLinks.howWaterManaged: How Water is Managed in California
